Table 1. Similarity of residues determined from algorithm (Fig. 3) after stabilization of values
(value “1”- similar, “0”- not similar).
The first thing that can be noticed while analyzing the data on the main diagonal of the
table is the fact that few amino acids reach high scores (C, K, M, Q, R and W). This means
that if in the middle position in a sequence of three residues is one of the above mentioned,
it is sufficient to analyze only these three residues to determine the 6 torsion angles adjacent

text.i: Scoring matrix based on similarity of protein backbone dihedral angles

page.text: to the residue. The second thing that can be noticed by analyzing generated table of similar-
ities is the fact that none of the two different sequences of 3 residues (where A
) deter-
mines a similar protein structures.
The third thing is that even three identical residues (A
=B
) rarely
determine the structure of the protein. The exception is the few residues (above), which
when present in the middle of the chain impose similar structures with a high probability.
For example sequence ECQ with high probability will have similar local structures for dif-
ferent proteins, but sequence AGH does not determine dihedral angles, and will create very
different local forms. Analysis of dihedral angles values for the specific sequence was not
the subject of this study.
The reason for such small similarity between the structures of similar strings of residues
is that compared sequences are too short.
For other amino acids (not listed above) all possibilities of longer amino acid sequence
alignment should be analyzed, which imposes to have a large database of sequences and the
corresponding dihedral angles (the number of records in the analysis of five amino acids is
= 3200000). For each sequence of five amino acids an appropriate structure in the data-
base of proteins should be possible to be found. However, this may prove impossible. That
is why score matrix is needed. In the absence of a counterpart in the database, a similar se-
quence (generating a similar structure) will be taken.

text.b: 4. Study of the 5 amino acid residues

shows the similarity of residues after stabilization of the values.

By analyzing the results of calculations it can be concluded that the same sequence of
five amino acid residues generates similar protein structures with high probability. Usually,
there is no need to consider sequences longer than 5 consecutive amino acids. High values
on the main diagonal of the matrix indicate that 5 identical consecutive amino acids are like-
ly to impose the same dihedral angles close to the central amino acid for each protein. For
example, if the dihedral angles for the sequence EAGHS near the amino acid G are known
then probably in other proteins of the same section of the sequence (EAGHS) will have the
same angles. It should be noted that shorter sequence (in this case, AGH), according to a
study of sections of three amino acid residues, does not give such a high probability. It is
therefore important to analyze the structure in an appropriately broad context (in this case 5
consecutive amino acids).
Comparison of the structures in the sequences which differ by only one residue shows a
great similarity of certain pairs (A-C, E-H, I-L, I-V, K-Q, K-R, L-M, Q-Y). Replacement of
one of these residues by the similar one should not change a lot the local structure of the
protein. You may also note that although the Q and K are similar, and K and R are similar,
Q and R do not show such a similarity. This is probably because the similarity calculation
method (3) is the product of differences in all the six dihedral angles. It is very sensitive to
even small differences. If even one of the six angles is significantly different in the two
compared sequences, the calculated similarity of structures will be close to 0.

text.i: Scoring matrix based on similarity of protein backbone dihedral angles

page.text: In this chapter a comparison of the scoring matrix derived above – let’s call it DASM
(Dihedral Angles Scoring Matrix) with other known matrices: PAM250 (appendix A),
BLOSUM62 (appendix B) and matrix of structural matches – lets call it in short: MSM (ap-
pendix C) will be done. PAM and BLOSUM matrices were derived by analyzing the rela-
tionships between relative proteins, while the third method analyzes the unrelated proteins
using geometric hashing. Comparison of the matrix derived in this work has shown both
similarities and differences with the three others.
A characteristic difference is the fact that DASM is more rigorous than the other arrays -
only 8 pairs of amino acid show similarity here (A-C, E-H, I-L, I-V, K-Q, K-R, L-M, Q-Y),
while in the PAM250 - 32 pairs, in the BLOSUM62 - 25 pairs and in the MSM - 68 pairs. 6
pairs classified as similar in DASM are also similar in the PAM250, BLOSUM62 and the
MSM - except for C-A and Q-Y couples which received a high score in DASM, while the
matrix PAM250, BLOSUM62 and MSM classified it as dissimilar.
Differences may come from a different approach to calculating the value of the matrix,
but it could also be the result of a relatively small amount of input data (the calculations
were taken from the PDBBind base with 1300 proteins), or disregarding of other considera-
tions such as availability of solvent near the analyzed section of the protein.
To predict the spatial protein structures found in living organisms homology modeling
and threading is often successfully used. These methods often use score marices BLOSUM
and PAM. As shown, they are not suitable for synthetic proteins as well, because synthetic
proteins are not related to existing proteins, therefore, there is a need to make a matrix of
similarities based solely on the structural properties. This matrix should be just as effective
for natural as synthetic proteins. This work can be considered an introduction to the study of
synthetic protein structure prediction and eventually perhaps to design new proteins.
Comparison of two protein sequences may have schematically the following form (dy-
namic programming without operations of insertion and deletion). If we denote two residues
as A and B then we can read the structural similarity of these residues from the table and we
have s(A
). To determine the structural similarity of two chains of residues A
and
, we can calculate the sum of the similarities of corresponding residues (4).
Instead of the sum of partial scores also the product (5) can be used.
It should be noted that in the second method calculated similarity is close to 1 only for very
short and similar (or identical) sequences. The greater the value of these assessments, the
higher possibility that similar spatial structures by sequences A and B will be generated.

Testing satisﬁability of logical formulas based on FPGA
Adrian Sadowski, Artur Jakubski
Institute of Computer and Information Sciences
Cz˛estochowa University of Technology
Abstract:
FPGA (Field Programmable Gate Array) allows direct programming the matrix of conﬁgura-
ble blocks and thus forming a programmable logic adapted to the problem being solved. The
appearance of programmable devices on the market and their higher capacity have resulted in
increase of interest in this technology in recent years.
In this paper we introduce the use of programmable devices for testing satisﬁability and tauto-
logical character of logical formulas. We compare the achieved results of the calculations for
the architecture created by us with the general-purpose architectures.
Keywords:
FPGA, SAT, VHDL
1. Introduction
The problem of testing satisﬁability (SAT) has been used in various types of applications
related to the study of algorithms correctness (including cryptographic algorithms), automatic
generation of test patterns, testing of logical formulas [1]. There are solutions to these pro-
blems of software, hardware or software-hardware. Currently, the most commonly used for
this purpose are SAT-solvers, which use recording the logical formula as the logical formula
in conjunctive normal form (CNF). These SAT-solvers test if for a logical formula transformed
to (k-SAT), recorded in CNF there exists such a valuation, for which the formula is true. The
basic algorithm for SAT-solvers is a DPLL algorithm that uses ’Basic Backtrack Algorithm’
and other heuristic [2]. However, SAT-solvers not always provide all results for all logical
formulas in reasonable time. Some of them only provide information whether the formula is
satisﬁable or not (if satisﬁable - these SAT-solvers do not provide all valuations). Therefore,
in the literature we can ﬁnd information about the complete SAT-solver, which returns infor-
mation on whether a logical formula is satisﬁable and for what valuations, and the SAT-solver
not providing complete information (about satisﬁability only).
In this paper we also use the naive method (brutal method), so check all the valuations of
variables occurring in the logical formula. The only limitation here is time to perform another
valuation in a single system clock cycle, which in our case is 20 ns (for 50 MHz frequency).
Estimated results for the number of variables of interval 32-64 are shown in Table 1. However,
the disadvantage of this approach is small number of propositional variables for which this
algorithm ﬁnds the valuation in a reasonable time. The advantage of this approach is ﬁnding
all the valuations, which give the result ’true’ for a given logical formula. In this paper, we
focus only on solving the satisﬁability and tautology problem by use of naive algorithm.

1.1. FPGA - on the example of Spartan 3AN
FPGA (Field Programmable Gate Array) consists of regular matrix of conﬁgurable blocks
CLB, which are built from arrays with a limited number of LUT inputs (usually less than 6)
[2]. Together with the appearance of programmable devices of larger capacity on the market,
the enormous potential of computing was recognized, which is one of the tasks of reconﬁgu-
rable FPGA systems. However, the basic elements of the programmable FPGA architecture
do not differ conceptually from those developed at early 80s of the last century. For designing
the FPGA the language HDL (Hardware Description Language) is used. The most often used
languages are VHDL and Verilog HDL. However, some other method is possible here. It is
based on converting the code written in C or C++ by use of Impulse C, MitrionC, Trent,
Handel-C, Cartec, into HDL [3].
The programmable systems allow to design the architecture due to an individual task. The
combination of FPGA architecture with a general-purpose processor, by use of transmission
protocols, gives greater possibilites of the task optimization.
Experimental studies were carried out by the synthesis of models of test control units,
which are described in VHDL.The synthesis was made in Xilinx ISE 11.3 software for Spartan
3AN FPGA (XC3S700AN).
2. Satisﬁability problem
Satisﬁability problem is one of the most important problems in the propositional calcu-
lus. Some problems can be reduced to a logical formula, which next is analyzed with taking
into account satisﬁability or tautological character. The example of such an application may
be cryptanalysis of certain cryptographic algorithms. The problem of satisﬁability of logical
formulas is equivalent to many problems of graph theory[4].
It can be said that satisﬁable formulas describe the world of situations that may take place.
This fact makes that through modeling many systems and testing the formulas expressing
their behavior, we sometimes can ﬁnd some defects of the tested system (through satisﬁability
verifying).
Satisﬁability problem is a propositional calculus question - whether for a given logical
formula, there exists such a substitution (valuation) of propositional variables that the formula
is true. Equivalent is that it is not true that the negation of this formula is tautology. Satisﬁa-
bility problem is decidable - we can check out all the substitutions, which are 2
N
, where N is
the number of variables of the formula. This method is called the naive algorithm. In order to
verify whether the formula is satisﬁable or not, the naive algorithm works in exponential time.
For the formula of N variables, at most 2
N
valuations need to be checked out. For practical
purposes, already for several dozens of variables, this algorithm often is not achievable. And
the problem whether it is signiﬁcantly faster to determine if the formula is satisﬁable than
Testing satisﬁability of logical formulas based on FPGA
checking out all variables valuations, is considered one of the most important problems in
mathematics (P = N P ).
2.1. Naive method of testing satisﬁability
Below we present the algorithm verifying satisﬁability of formula by use of naive method.
The input is the formula φ and N - the number of variables of the formula φ. Loop 2 is repeated
for all valuations, from the valuation consisting of N values equal 0 to N values equal 1 (run

2.2. Logical formula
In general, for the study satisﬁability of logical formulas there are used formulas in CNF
form. The number of propositional variables in our study is in the range from 24 to 32. The
number of formula clauses stored in the k-SAT for N propositional variables cannot be less
than N/k. The example of tested formula is the following formula, for N = 32 propositional
variables:
F=((not temp(3) or temp(4) or temp(7)) and (not temp(3) or not temp(10) or not temp(16))
and (not temp(17) or not temp(15) or not temp(9)) and (temp(8) or not temp(18) or temp(17))
and (not temp(21) or not temp(31) or not temp(27)) and (temp(14) or not temp(22) or temp(11))
and (temp(1) or temp(6) or temp(14)) and (temp(15) or not temp(18) or temp(2)) and (temp(16)
or temp(14) or not temp(28)) and (temp(12) or not temp(21) or temp(23)) and (temp(2) or

not temp(5) or temp(3)) and (temp(12) or temp(19) or temp(21)) and (temp(18) or temp(4)
or temp(31)) and (not temp(4) or not temp(0) or not temp(5)) and (temp(26) or not temp(29)
or temp(11)) and (temp(15) or temp(29) or not temp(13)) and (temp(24) or not temp(11) or
temp(18)) and (not temp(15) or not temp(26) or temp(6)) and (not temp(20) or not temp(25)
or not temp(30)) and (temp(0) or temp(6) or temp(16)) and temp(31) and temp(0)).
2.3. Reconﬁgured system architecture
The architecture for testing logical formulas based on the naive algorithm, is built of three
concurrent processes, ”clock_manager”, ”tx_proc”, ”count” (Figure 1). The system operates
at a clock frequency of 50MHz (CLK). The process of ”clock_manager” adjusts the clock
frequency to the UART (Universal Asynchronous Receiver and Transmitter) protocol. Inside
the process ”tx_proc” there is built the state machine (its architecture) to transmit and receive
Adrian Sadowski, Artur Jakubski
data, according to the UART.The satisﬁability testing block is included in the process ”count”,
from which the valuations are sent to CPU, for F = ”1” of the formula.
Rysunek 1. FPGA architecture of the system for testing satisﬁability by use of naive algorithm
2.4. The results
The results of the study relate to the same logical formula, tested in individual cases for
the CPU and FPGA. All FPGA times given in the table (Table 2) show that the result of
ﬁnding valuation is less than one second. More accurate results would be estimated results
only (based on the clock frequency of the FPGA and the number of pulses generated for each
of the cases). These values are less than one second for those sample formulas. Obtaining
more accurate results was not the goal of our research. The goal of the paper is showing that
the use of programmable devices for this algorithm gives a several dozen times acceleration.
In our study we have compared the architecture dedicated for the satisﬁability problem
with the architecture of general-purpose (CPU) for the some task. Our research is focused on
resolving the satisﬁability problem and the problem of tautological character of the logical
formula.

The processor used for comparing our architecture with the architecture of general purpose
was Intel Atom N450, running on Linux Ubuntu. For this purpose, we created the programs
Testing satisﬁability of logical formulas based on FPGA
written in C++. The ﬁrst one operates on the variables (bool type) and veriﬁes satisﬁability and
tautological character of the formula through, increasing the counter. The second one operates
on a bitset container and through built-in mechanisms operates much faster.
It can be seen however that the architecture dedicated to an individual task (verifying satis-
ﬁability of the logical formula of 32 variables) runs 70 times faster than the general-purpose
architecture (Table 2). In the experiment we used the Spartan 3AN (clock frequency - 50
MHz) and the Intel Atom N450 processor of 1,6 GHz frequency [5].
3. Introduction to SAT-solver problem for the FPGA
In Boolean logic, the formula is in conjunctive normal form (CNF) if it is a conjunction
of clauses, where the clause is a disjunction of literals, where the literal and its complement
cannot appear in the same clause. Formula is a disjunctive normal form (DNF) when is the
disjunction of conjunctive clauses. Davis and Putnam proposed the use of CNF for satisﬁa-
bility testing as early as 1958 in an unpublished manuscript [6]. This idea has been extended
to all the essentials of modern DPLL variants. Algorithm DPLL was extended by resolution
rule by Tseitin [7]. In mathematical logic and automated theorem proving, resolution is a rule
of inference leading to a refutation theorem-proving technique for sentences in propositional
logic and ﬁrst-order logic. In other words, iteratively applying the resolution rule in a suitable
way allows for telling whether a propositional formula is satisﬁable and for proving that a
ﬁrst-order formula is unsatisﬁable; this method may prove the satisﬁability of the ﬁrst-order
satisﬁable formula, but not always, as it is the case for all methods for ﬁrst-order logic. Reso-
lution was introduced by John Alan Robinson in 1965. The results of applying the FPGA for
satisﬁability formulas veriﬁying in CNF form, are given in Handbook of Satisﬁability (2009)
4. Future work
Through linking pipelining and pararelism [9] [10] [11] it will bee created the architecture
to test satysﬁability by use of the naive method. We are going to divide our parallel architecture
into 4, 16, 32, 64 etc. blocks.
Another task is creating a parallel pipelined SAT-solver for the FPGA.

text.i: Maria Curie Sklodowska University, Institute of Computer Science
There are different levels at which parallelism can be introduced to the database system
but in general there are two types of parallel optimization tasks for databases. First, that is a
speedup in query execution time. The second task is such a scaleup of the system that it was
able to execute more tasks in the time unit. This situation is the subject of interest of the fol-
Authors introduce the parallelization method based on the speculative execution for the
database systems which are expected to give answers to complex queries coming from differ-
ent sources as soon as possible. Assume that W queries wait for execution and that the best
execution plan developed by the DBMS for the first query does not use full available compu-
ting power. Thus, in parallel to the first query, some excessive computations can be executed,
which in further steps would reduce the execution time of the consecutive queries increasing
The paper introduces the idea of speculative computations, presents possible risks and
benefits of using this method and also an analyses of possible execution time reduction for dif-

page.text: Bigger and more sophisticated data stored in databases caused an increase in demands
for database managements systems. Throughput requirements for I/O devices and CPU,
increasing amount of stored data and multiple users become a serious efficiency problem for
single, isolated machines. To fulfill those high demands it was essential that DBMS’s de-
rived from parallel mechanisms. Parallel DBMS’s can be implemented on multicore or mul-
tinode machines. Query optimization for multinode systems concerns mainly data partition-
ing and availability of data sources. The subject of interest of this paper are multicore sys-
tems and interquery parallelism. One of the phases of the query execution is finding the ex-
ecution plan suitable for a particular query. Execution plan defines an execution order of
operators that build query. Unfortunately in case of parallel databases query optimization is
way more complicated than for sequential DBMS’s. The number of parallel plans is usually
higher than for sequential databases[1,2].
The system must often process upcoming queries in a certain order. Thus the optimizer
while creating the execution plan can take under consideration a few of consecutive await-
ing queries. Such out-of-order method of analyzing and query processing we would call a
speculative execution. Speculative action is considered as some work done in anticipation of
some event happening. This offers opportunities of gain or loss that depend on speculation

text.i: Polska Akademia Nauk Oddział w Gdańsku, Komisja Informatyki

page.text: accuracy [3]. In computer architecture, speculative execution is the process of executing
instructions ahead of their normal schedule. In query execution speculative computations
can be considered on three levels. Speculative input data for operators which traditionally
couldn’t be executed before determining its input data. Speculative DB state related to pos-
sible occurrence of modifying queries. And last but not least speculative query which is ex-
pected to maximize benefits based on analyses of only a subgroup of awaiting queries.
Unfortunately speculations and overheads are inseparable especially when there is a lot
of modifying queries in line. As long as the benefits of successful speculative execution
outweight the total overhead of its use, the technique is considered a profitable activity.
The first part of the paper introduces a notation, which is used to represent query struc-
ture and to estimate the cost of a query execution. The consecutive parts describe the pro-
posed optimization method and conduct a discussion of such system efficiency. The sum-
mary outlines the direction of future research.
There are many different forms of parallelism for database processing, including (I) in-
terquery parallelism, (II) intraquery parallelism, (III) mixed parallelism.
Interquery parallelism is “parallelism among queries” – that is, different queries or
transactions are executed in parallel with one another. The primary use of interquery paral-
lelism is to scale up transaction processing system in supporting a large number of transac-
tions per second. In single-processor database system queries form a queue, since only one
of them can be processed at any given time. With interquery parallelism, the waiting time of
each query in the queue is reduced, and overall completion time is improved[4].
A query to a database, such as sort, select, project, join etc. is normally divided into mul-
tiple operations. Intraquery parallelism is an execution of a single query in parallel on mul-
tiple processors and disks. Therefore, intraquery parallelism is “parallelism within a que-
ry”[5]. Execution of a single query can be parallelized in two ways: (i) Intraoperation par-
allelism. We can speedup the processing of a query by parallelizing the execution of each
individual operation, such as parallel sort, parallel search, etc. The main issues of in-
traoperation parallelism are: how the operation can be arranged so that it can perform on
different data sets, and how the data is partitioned in order for an operation to work on it.
Therefore, in database processing, intraoperation parallelism raises the need for formulating
parallel versions of basic sequential database operations, including: (a) parallel search, (b)
parallel sort, (c) parallel group by/ aggregate and (d) parallel join[6]. (ii)Interoperation
parallelism is where parallelism is created by concurrently executing different operations
within the same query. There are two forms of interoperation parallelism: (a) pipelined par-
allelism and (b) independent parallelism. In pipelining, the output records of one operator
are consumed by a second operator, even before the first operator has produced the entire
set of records. The major advantage of pipelined execution is that we can carry out a se-
quence of operations without writing any of the intermediate results to disk. Pipelined paral-
lelism is useful with a small number of processors but does not scale up well for various
reasons. First, pipeline chains generally do not attain sufficient length to provide a high de-
gree of parallelism. Second, it is not possible to pipeline those operators that do not produce
output until all inputs have been accessed, Third, only marginal speedup is obtained for the
frequent cases in which one operator’s execution cost is much higher than that of the others.
Independent parallelism is where operations in a query that do not depend on one another
can be executed in parallel. Like pipelined parallelism, independent parallelism does not
provide a high degree of parallelism, because of limited number of independent operations

text.i: The example of speculative execution for multiple query execution systems

page.text: within a query, and is less useful in a highly parallel system, although it is useful with a
lower degree of parallelism. In practice, a mixture of all possible parallelism forms is used
in hope to higher speedup or better scaleup[7]. The following picture presents schema of
database parallelism types.
Figure 1. Database parallelism scheme
A parallel optimizer is expected to define an abstract parallel execution model. This
model is similar to an algebraic machine that is a set of algorithms for relational operators
with more complex rules to combine these algorithms and execute them in parallel. The
process of choosing the query execution strategy consists of the series of transformations
that replace algebraic expressions with some other equivalent expressions which can be
computed more effectively. Most of SQL queries can be defined with a relatively small
number of classical relational algebra operators. This chapter provides a general survey of
algebraic operators which in the further parts are used for query representation and execu-
tion cost analysis.
The operations of the traditional relational algebra fall into four broad classes:
a)
The usual set operations – UNION
∪, INTERSECTION ∩, and DIFFERENCE ⁄ –
applied to relations
b)
Operations that remove parts of a relation: SELECTION eliminates some rows,
PROJECTION eliminates some columns
c)
Operations that combine the tuples of two relations, including Cartesian product and
various kinds of join operations, which selectively pair tuples from two relations
d)
An operation called “renaming” that does not affect the tuples of a relation, but
changes the relation schema i.e., the names of the attributes and/or the name of the
relation itself [8]
The SELECTION operator denoted as
( ), applied to a relation R, produces a new re-
lation with a subset of R’s tuples. The tuples in the resulting relation are those satisfying the
condition C that involves the attributes of R. The condition C can contain mathematical,
textual and logical operators. It is important that the only operands in C are either constants
or attributes of R. Selection is an equivalent of the WHERE clause.
The PROJECTION operator is used to produce from a relation R a new relation that has
only some of R’s columns. The value of expression
( ) is a relation that has only
the columns for attributes
} of R. Projection is an equivalence of the SE-
LECT clause.
The CARTESIAN PRODUCT
of two sets R and S is the set of pairs that can be
formed by choosing the first element of the pair to be any element of R and the second any
element of S. However, if R and S should happen to have some attributes in common, then
an ambiguous attribute will be qualified with the name of its original relation
Product is an equivalent of the relations list from FROM clause, which product is filtered to
meet conditions from the WHERE clause.
More often than we want to take the product of two relations, we find a need to join
them by pairing only those tuples that match in some way. The simplest sort of match is the
NATURAL JOIN of two relations R and S, denoted
⋈ , in which we pair only those
tuples from R and S that agree in whatever attributes are common to the schemas of R and S.
As in product, the output tuple has one component for each of the attributes in the union of
the schemas of R and S, qualified if needed. The natural join, commonly used in typical que-
ries, assumes pairing tuples using equals operators. For that purpose, we have related nota-
tion called the THETA JOIN. The notation for a theta-join of relations R and S based on
condition C is
where C has a form of any logical condition referring to R and S at-
tributes[9].
Example 1: Assume there is a relation Movie(movie_id, title, year, length, tape, studio,
starName) and that the following query was formulated in SQL:
SELECT title, year FROM Movie WHERE length≥100 AND studio=’Fox’
This query expressed with relational algebra operators would have the following form:
(Movie)), or alternatively
(Movie)).
The complexity of queries which can be built over a relational database varies. The
complexity results from different determinants such as the number of referenced relations,
join criteria, chosen attributes, aggregate functions, sorting, etc. The graph model is a very
convenient way of representing queries with differential structure. Such model is very ge-
neric and thus it can be easily adjusted to represent queries expressed in different query lan-
guages. It can also be fairly easily visualized and thus simplifies query analysis. The fol-
lowing paragraph presents the set of rules for building query graph.
The Database D consists of the relations
(i=1..n). Each relation
has a set of attrib-
utes.
stands for the attribute j of the relation
. Each query is represented by its graph
) . The construction of this graph must comply with the following assumptions:
Three types of vertexes are allowed[10]:
Relation vertex (R) – one for each relation in a query
Attribute vertex (A) – one for each attribute from a query, duplicates of those ver-
texes are possible if the same attribute appears in a few clauses of a query
Value vertex (
Ω) – one for each value or set of values from a query
Three basic types of edges are allowed:
Membership edges -
– for each attribute
projected from a relation
, there is a
membership edge:
(SELECT clause)

denotes a comparison operator (e.g. =,<,>,LIKE), there is a predicate edge. If

The three above types of edges are enough to represent any SPJ (selection-projection-
join) query[11]. In order to represent queries with nesting we need to develop additional
rules for the query graph. So far we assume that a subquery can be used only in a WHERE
clause, where it can be treated as a list of values or a single value that participates in a pred-
